Detailed Description

Prototypes and macros for using "opts_" Callback based command line options handler.

Define Documentation

#define _GNU_SOURCE
 

enables the long options processing in getopt.h

#define OPTS_DEF (  short_name,
long_name,
description    ) 
 

Value:

opts_def(short_name,long_name,description,NULL, \
                NULL,NULL)
declares a option with no action, or argument. The calling program must "catch" this option (don't do this unless you have to)

#define OPTS_DEF_ARG (  short_name,
long_name,
description,
arg_name    ) 
 

Value:

opts_def(short_name,long_name,description,arg_name,     \
                NULL,NULL)
declares an option with no action. The calling program must catch this option (don't do this unless you have to)

#define OPTS_DEF_CLEAR (  short_name,
long_name,
description,
v    ) 
 

Value:

opts_def(short_name,long_name,description,NULL,         \
                opts_action_clear,(void *)&(v))
declares an option which sets v to 0

#define OPTS_DEF_INCR (  short_name,
long_name,
description,
v    ) 
 

Value:

opts_def(short_name,long_name,description,NULL,         \
                opts_action_incr,(void *)&(v))
declares an option which increments v

#define OPTS_DEF_SET (  short_name,
long_name,
description,
v    ) 
 

Value:

opts_def(short_name,long_name,description,NULL,         \
                opts_action_set,(void *)&(v))
declares an option which sets v to 1

#define OPTS_DEF_STRTOL (  short_name,
long_name,
description,
arg_name,
v    ) 
 

Value:

opts_def(short_name,long_name,description,arg_name,             \
                opts_action_strtol,(void *)&(v))
declares an option which takes a "long" argument and stores it in v

#define OPTS_LIM   (OPTS_MAX + 1)
 

The highest valid ordinal for an option

#define OPTS_MAX   UCHAR_MAX
 

The most options we can have. Options > CHAR_MAX will have no short names

Typedef Documentation

typedef int(* T_opts_action)(void *)
 

The option handling callback function type

Function Documentation

int opts_action_clear (  void *    ptr_to_long ) 
 

callback action to zero a long value if a flag is present

Returns:
0 for success non-zero for failure

int opts_action_incr (  void *    ptr_to_long ) 
 

callback action to increment a long value if a flag is present

Returns:
0 for success non-zero for failure

int opts_action_set (  void *    ptr_to_long ) 
 

callback action to set to 1 a long value if a flag is present

Returns:
0 for success non-zero for failure

int opts_action_strtol (  void *    ptr_to_long ) 
 

callback action to set long value to the supplied argument if a flag is present

Returns:
0 for success non-zero for failure

int opts_action_usage (  void *    ignored ) 
 

callback action display the usage message if a flag is present

Returns:
0 for success non-zero for failure

int opts_action_version (  void *    ignored ) 
 

callback action display the usage version message if a flag is present

Returns:
0 for success non-zero for failure

void opts_def (  char    short_name,
char *    long_name,
char *    description,
char *    arg_name,
T_opts_action    action,
void *    data
) 
 

add the given option to the opts_table

Parameters:
short_name  the 1 character that uniquely identifies this option
long_name  the long (no spaces) name for this option. Must be non-NULL.
description  descriptive text for this option. If arg_name is non-NULL, %s in description will insert arg_name.
arg_name  the descriptive name of the argument the option takes (if an option takes an argument), or NULL if it doesn't.
action  the callback action if the flag is found
data  pointer to the data the callback will need.

int opts_getopt (  int    argc,
char *const *    argv
) 
 

parse the known options, calling their callback actions, and returning on unknown options with the identical semantics of getopt

Parameters:
argc  the argument count
argv  the argument array
Returns:
-1 for end of arguments, anything else for an unknown options

void opts_init (  const char *    progname,
const char *    progversion
) 
 

initialize the "opts_" Callback based command line options handler subsystem. Call this before calling

Returns:
0 for success non-zero for failure
